subject: Sleep
title: Depression and Oversleeping
description: A 60-second lesson on Depression and Oversleeping.

hook.text: Some depressed people can't sleep at all. Others sleep 12 or more hours and still feel exhausted. Same illness, opposite symptoms.

buildup.text: About 15 percent of depressed patients experience hypersomnia instead of insomnia.

discovery.text: Depressive hypersomnia involves increased total sleep time but reduced deep sleep, making rest unrestorative.

twist.text: Oversleeping in depression isn't restful sleep. It's the brain withdrawing from a world it finds painful.

climax.text: This withdrawal behavior reinforces depression by reducing social contact, light exposure, and physical activity.

punchline.text: Sleeping too much in depression isn't rest. It's hiding.

quiz.question: Why is oversleeping in depression not restorative?
options: Deep sleep is reduced even though total sleep time increases
Because they wake up too often
